captions.text: LAST WEEK...

(LAUGHTER)
OH, (BLEEP) JUST GOT REAL.

LAST WEEK, THE OBAMA
ADMINISTRATION AND IRAN IN

COOPERATION WITH RUSSIA, FRANCE,
BRITAIN, GERMANY AND CHINA,

REACHED AN HISTORIC
OUTLINE OF A FRAMEWORK

OF AN OUTLINE OF A
POTENTIAL DRAFT FOR A PRE-FINAL

TENTATIVE NUCLEAR DEAL
ARRANGEMENT!
PENDING APPROVAL.

(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)
BUT FIRST, CONGRESS HAS SOME
CONCERNS.

>> THIS DEAL DOESN'T DISMANTLE
ONE CENTRIFUGE, IT DOESN'T CLOSE
ONE SITE.
>> NO ONE TRUSTS IRAN.

>> I DON'T TRUST THE LEADERSHIP
OF IRAN.

>> THERE SHOULD HAVE BEEN A
CLEAR RECOGNITION ON THEIR PART

THAT ISRAEL HAS A RIGHT TO
EXIST AS A JEWISH STATE.

>> I WOULDN'T HAVE STARTED THESE
NEGOTIATIONS TO BEGIN WITH.
>> Jon: WHAT!

SO I GUESS WE'RE GIVING CEDING
TO LIARS AND ANTI-SEMITES IN A

NEGOTIATION THAT NEVER
SHOULD HAVE EXISTED BUT

OTHER THAN THAT,
GOOD FIRST DRAFT.

WHAT COURSE OF ACTION IF NOT A
TREATY WOULD CONGRESS RECOMMEND?

>> SOMETHING ALONG THE LINES OF
WHAT PRESIDENT CLINTON DID IN

DECEMBER 1998, SEVERAL DAYS OF
AIR AND NAVAL BOMBING

AGAINST IRAQ'S WEAPONS OF MASS
DESTRUCTION FACILITIES.
>> Jon: OH, RIGHT!

1998, CLINTON SENT MISSILES IN
THERE IN OPERATION I GUESS
THAT'S THAT.

(LAUGHTER)
YEAH, THAT 1998 BOMBING FIXED

IRAQ FOREVER, TRANSITIONING THAT
COUNTRY FROM A DICTATORSHIP

TO AN AMERICAN-LOVING
KITTEN-AND-FUDGE-BASED
DEMOCRACY.

EVERYONE LOVES A
KITTEN-AND-FUDGE-BASED

--DEMOCRACY. BUT THE TRUTH
IS, EVEN IF THE SENATORS --
(LAUGHTER)

REALLY? HONESTLY, JUST ADDED A
[BLEEP] T. THAT'S ALL WE DID.

EVEN IF THE SENATORS DID THINK
THE DEAL WITH IRAN WAS A GOOD

DEAL, THE SENATORS WOULD STILL
HAVE TO FULFILL THEIR
CONSTITUTIONAL OBLIGATION.

>> NO SENATE OR HOUSE SHOULD
EVER LET ANY PRESIDENT DO AWAY

WITH CONGRESSIONAL SANCTIONS
CREATED BY THE BODIES WITHOUT
THEIR APPROVAL.

>> I THINK IT'S CRITICAL THAT IS
SENATE APPROVE THIS LIKE WE
DO ANY TREATY.

>> IT REQUIRES THE ADVICE AND
CONSENT OF THE UNITED STATES
SENATE.
>> Jon: SLOW DOWN THERE, McCAIN!

SENATE'S ALREADY IN SESSION,
LIKE, THREE DAYS A MONTH!

(LAUGHTER)
YOU DON'T WANT TO OVERLOAD YOUR
SCHEDULE, BLOW A GASKET.
OF COURSE!

THE CONSTITUTION ALSO GIVES
CONGRESS THE RESPONSIBILITY TO
DECLARE WAR.

HOW CONCERNED ARE THEY WITH
DEFENDING THAT AUTHORITY FROM
PRESIDENTIAL OVERREACH?

>> I DON'T WANT TO LIMIT OUR
COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF.

>> THIS RESOLUTION SAYS WIN A
WAR, IT TAKES GROUND TROOPS
WHEREVER IT TAKES.

>> A GUY NAMED RONALD REAGAN
INVADED A SOVEREIGN, SMALL

SOVEREIGN NATION CALLED
GRENADA, YOU KNOW, AND NOTIFIED

EVERYBODY THE NEXT MORNING
AFTER, AFTER IT WAS COMPLETED.

>> CONGRESS SHOULD SORT OF SHUT
UP.

>> Jon: THE PRESIDENT NEEDS TO
FOCUS, EVERYBODY!
HE'S BOMBING PEOPLE!

MY ADVICE IS THAT CONGRESS
CONSENT TO A HOT CUP OF SHUT
THE (BLEEP) UP!
DELAWARE!
DELAWARE!

(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)
DELAWARE, WHEN THE PRESIDENT'S

BOMBING PEOPLE, YOU SO MUCH SAY
A WORD I WILL SHOVE YOU SO FAR

UP MASSACHUSETTS' ASS, YOU WILL
SMELL MAINE!
(LAUGHTER)
A LOT OF THE TOUGH TALK FROM --

AS A MATTER OF FACT, CONGRESS IS
SO LAX IN THEIR WAR-MAKING

OVERSIGHT, THE PRESIDENT HIMSELF
IS SOMEWHAT UNCOMFORTABLE WITH

THE AMOUNT OF FIRE IN HIS POWER
LIKE HIS DRONE STRIKE AUTHORITY.

>> ONE OF THE THINGS WE'VE GOT
TO DO IS PUT A LEGAL

ARCHITECTURE IN PLACE AND WE
NEED CONGRESSIONAL HELP TO DO

THAT TO MAKE SURE THAT NOT ONLY
AM I REINED IN BUT ANY PRESIDENT

IS IN TERMS OF SOME OF THE
DECISIONS WE'RE MAKING.

>> Jon: STOP ME CONGRESS
BEFORE I KILL -- OH, TOO LATE.

TURNS OUT, WHEN IT COMES TO
BOMBING COUNTRIES OR SENDING

ADVISORS TO COUNTRIES OR DRONE
STRIKING COUNTRIES, CONGRESS IS
THE GIRL WHO JUST CAN'T SAY NO.

BUT WHEN IT COMES TO COOPERATING
WITH COUNTRIES, TREATIES -- HOLD
ON THERE!
WHAT ARE YOU DOING, MISTER?

LIKE THE SMALL ARMS TREATY TO
STOP THE ILLEGAL INTERNATIONAL

TRADE OF ARMS RATIFIED BY 66
OTHER COUNTRIES.

>> WHY IN THE WORLD WOULD
SOMEBODY WANT TO GIVE TO CEDE

TO THE UNITED NATIONS OR ANY
MULTI-NATIONAL GROUP THE POWER

TO MAKE DETERMINATIONS AS TO
WHOM, WITH WHOM WE TRADE ARMS.

>> THIS TREATY WILL INFRINGE ON
THE SECOND AMENDMENT RIGHTS OF
AMERICAN GUN OWNERS.

>> Jon: BLACK MARKET SOMALI
ARMS TRAFFICKING DOESN'T KILL
PEOPLE.

PEOPLE WHO BUY BLACK MARKET
SOMALI ARMS -- OH, FORGET IT!

(LAUGHTER)
OR THE LAW OF THE SEA TREATY

WHICH CREATES GUIDELINES FOR HOW
COUNTRIES CAN RESPONSIBLY USE

MARINE NATURAL RESOURCES,
RATIFIED BY 167 COUNTRIES OR
IT'S KNOWN, EARTH MINUS US.

>> WHAT IT DOES IN JUST A ONE
SENTENCE FORM IS TO RELINQUISH

OUR SOVEREIGNTY OVER 70% OF THE
WORLD.

>> Jon: WHAT ARE WE THE
SPANISH ARMADA?

AS YOU KNOW, AMERICA CURRENTLY
OWNS THE OCEANS.

EVER SINCE PRESIDENT NIXON BLEW
ON NEPTUNE'S FABLED CONCH SHELL
AND BECAME PRINCE OF THE DEEP!

(LAUGHTER)
OR -- AND THE ONE IS HONESTLY

HARD TO BELIEVE THAT WE WON'T
RATIFY, THE TREATY TO PROMOTE

RIGHTS FOR THE DISABLED
RATIFIED BY 153 NATIONS.

>> IN ALL HONESTY, I DON'T WANT
TO LOSE OUR SOVEREIGNTY IN THIS
ISSUE.

>> Jon: OH! I DON'T WANT SOME
ONE WORLD BLACK HELICOPTER

ILLUMINATI COMING HERE AND
TELLING US WHICH RAMP NEEDS
TO GO IN FRONT OF WHICH LIBRARY!

AND IT'S NOT ALWAYS THAT WE'RE
ALWAYS WORKING AGAINST OTHER

COUNTRIES, WE DO WORK WITH OTHER
COUNTRIES, WE DO IT ALL THE
TIME.

>> WELL, CERTAINLY WE NEED OTHER
PARTNERS.

I MEAN, WE NEED THESE OTHER ARAB
COUNTRIES TO STEP IN.

>> THE UNITED STATES MUST BE
COMMITTED TO BUILDING A

COALITION THAT ASSISTS THE
IRAQI, KURDISH AND FREE SYRIAN
FORCES.

>> DEMONSTRATE OUR COMMITMENT TO
THE GLOBAL COALITION IN

DEFEATING THIS RADICAL ISLAMIC
ORGANIZATION.

>> AMERICAN SOLDIERS NEED TO GO
BACK TO SYRIA AND IRAQ AS PART

OF THE COALITION --
>> Jon: SEE?

YOU WANT TO WORK WITH THE UNITED
STATES, HUH?

WELL, THERE'S ONLY TWO THINGS
YOU CAN DO WITH RAMPS -- BUILD
'EM OR BOMB 'EM.

(LAUGHTER)
AND I DON'T SEE NO BUILDING RAMP
MATERIALS.

(LAUGHTER)
WHICH BRINGS US TO THE QUESTION,

WHY ARE WE SO (BLEEP) CAUTIOUS
AND UNWILLING TO COOPERATE WITH

THE GLOBAL COMMUNITY ON
NON-MILITARY AGREEMENTS?

>> WHENEVER A BILL OR A TREATY
IS PASSED, THERE ARE SOME
UNINTENDED CONSEQUENCES.

>> LET'S DO IT WITHOUT ENMESHING
OUR NATION INTO ANOTHER BINDING

INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATION THAT
WILL CAUSE MORE GRIEF THAN
BENEFIT.

>> YOU ALSO NEED TO PAY VERY
CAREFUL ATTENTION TO THOSE

CONSEQUENCES THAT ARE UNINTENDED
BECAUSE THAT IS WHERE THE DANGER
TRULY LIES.

>> Jon: YES, THE UNINTENDED
CONSEQUENCES OF TRYING TO MAKE
PEACE!

OUR CONGRESS IS INCREDIBLY
CAUTIOUS ABOUT TREATIES BECAUSE

YOU NEVER KNOW THE BLOW-BACK
PEACEFUL COOPERATION CAN HAVE!
WE SEE IT ALL THE TIME!

MAYBE IF WE HADN'T BEEN SO
EAGER TO COLLECT HALLOWEEN

PENNIES FOR UNICEF, IRAQ WOULD
BE A STABLE COUNTRY TODAY.

AND I.S.I.S. WOULD NEVER GET A
FOOTHOLD.

BUT THAT'S THE KIND OF GOODNESS
BAKED INTO OUR CONSTITUTION, TO

MAKE PEACE, TWO-THIRDS OF THE
SENATE NEED TO COME ALONG.
YOU WANT TO GO TO WAR, THOUGH?
SIMPLE MAJORITY.

AND A QUICK TIP IF YOU CALL IT
SOMETHING ELSE, YOU CAN DO
WHATEVER THE (BLEEP) YOU WANT.

WE'RE THE EDWARD SCISSORHANDS OF
COUNTRIES.

comments.author: alain belanger

comments.text:
I agree with everything Jon Stewart believes in except his stance on guns. 
I really understand that many countries desire peace as they should but we 
have not advanced to the point where disarming our citizens is wise. 
America would rush to the aid of any European country if they were invaded 
or in the event of a tyrannical government forcing its way into power if 
their own military was compromised and couldn't defend the country. However 
as history has shown us time and again every empire will eventually fall, I 
am sure it will take hundreds of years or an entire republican election 
sweep to bring our country down but it can happen. Hitler showed us all 
what can happen when he rolled across Europe taking every country he wanted 
and the same thing could happen in this day and time. He didn't invade 
Switzerland though did he? It is better to have your citizens armed to help 
the military defend. Besides guns do not make violence they are just a tool 
that can be used for violence. There are several ways to drop the gun 
murder rate like ending the war on drugs among other things. Not only would 
we save a fortune by just letting clinics dispense drugs for free in a safe 
environment but there would no longer be a need for drug related violence. 
Also the more we educate our poor and less privileged the less likely they 
would turn to a violent lifestyle. I cant believe that people have not put 
it together that the war on drugs brought with it war on the streets but as 
usual most people try to fix something the wrong way. If our government 
really keeps our best interests at heart and looks out for the people over 
wall street and corporations then people wouldn't be as angry or as 
desperate. I really wish my fellow democrats would stop blaming the gun 
when it is the heart of man that is the real culprit.﻿

comments.author: Alvin Lee

comments.text:
I think that the reasoning as to why congress is so cautious is yeah. They 
don't want any unintended consequences to decisions in a treaty. Look at 
almost 100 years ago at the treaty of Versailles that ended WWI. Thanks to 
that treaty the conditions were created so that Fascism could take root and 
helped kickstart the second world war. Then you have treaties or just 
conflicts ending in general like the gulf war where while we did win and 
drive Hussein out of Kuwait, it also created the chance for extremist 
groups to take over or at the very least become a threat.
However while I do understand why they're so cautious, I'd be lying if I 
said I wasn't mad at them taking their sweet time to approve of treaties or 
downright ignoring them just because they don't want to have any unforeseen 
consequences.﻿
comments.author: Emma Petersen

comments.text:
+Emma Petersen When the US drove Saddam out of Kuwait he still had total 
control over Iraq. It was when they overthrew him they caused the 
instability we see today. And comparing the Versailles with a UN treaty is 
faaaaaar reaching.

comments.author: Wuster L

comments.text:
+Wuster L Yeah, I'm hearing you. Australia sells immense amounts of coal to 
the rest of the world then pretends global warming doesn't exist... At 
least you guys are talking about it. Hopefully CSG is just an 'interim 
measure' until alternative energy takes off, like the politicians 
say... hmmm. They way I see it, the oil guys have invested trillions in 
their way, so they've doing everything they can to stall things. Just the 
Alaska pipeline cost a fortune, add in all the ships, mining gear, oil 
platforms. They're not going to let all that go quietly. No wonder there's 
such misinformation on climate change in the media. Its like the tobacco 
lobby on steroids.
comments.author: Duncan Wallace

comments.text:

comments.author: Wuster L

comments.text:
+Dathotness4ya Yeah, sorry I was being ironic. Don't worry too much about 
being embarrassed to be American. I think things have got a lot better 
under Obama (from someone looking in from the outside), and there is plenty 
about America which inspires people. Personally I like the way Americans 
encourage innovation. You've also got an amazing National Parks service & 
yes, even some inspirational & visionary politicians. E.G. just this week 
California, one of the largest economies in the world, decided to set 40% 
emissions reduction targets. In Australia our idiotic government scrapped a 
carbon tax that was working to reduce emissions because they don't believe 
climate change is real. Now that is embarrassing!

comments.text:
Actually, yes, America kind of owns the ocean.
A friend of mine had visited the US to buy a boat, with which he had then 
planned to sail through the Carribean and back to Europe. His first stop 
WOULD have been Cuba.
He was literally stopped by American Patrol boats when he had Havanna in 
sight. I was supposed to meet him in Havanna to join his sailing tour and I 
had already gotten the message that he could see Havanna..... followed by 3 
days of silence and eventually the message that the US coast guard had 
stopped them right in front of Cuban waters to escort them back to Florida.
Here is the thing. By international law, that does count as piratery. 
Countries only have control over the 12 mile zone, which for the US, 
definitely does not extent until Cuba's 12 mile zone. Then again, the US is 
unfortunately not exactly known to follow international laws and 
regulations.﻿
comments.author: yakumo961

comments.text:
+yakumo961 Exactly. That kind of fanaticism has only been the majority in 
Nazi Germany and the USSR, those types of countries. A people who blindly 
follow their government and their pride are sheep.
comments.author: Ryoushadow

comments.text:
+Moreththerogue I wasnt talking about pride in general, but the kind of 
pride that is going into nationalism, into the idea that one is superior 
and is entitled to more due to one's nationality.
I am not accusing the entire US of this, but I honestly feel that this kind 
of pride is the most present in the US.
And why is the US criticized seemingly more than other countries? Because 
the US is breaking INTERNATIONAL laws so often. It is the FOREIGN policy 
that is so heavily critical in the US. Add to that the immense power of the 
US and therefore the shock that comes, when we see some of the political 
activity from other countries.
If countries like Russia, China, etc. would interfere with foreign policies 
and ignore INTERNATIONAL laws the way the US did, the US would probably 
call for war within the NATO nations.
I do not want to generalize here. All countries have their issues and all 
countries have ignorant citizens. What makes the US stand out is that these 
issues are taking place in the most powerful country of the world, that 
these issues are taken into other countries far too often, that hypocrisy 
seems to occur far too often and that even with all these problems, there 
are seemingly more citizens trying to justify these problems and even 
taking pride in them than in any other country.
comments.author: yakumo961

comments.text:
+yakumo961
  I personally think everyone should be just as proud of their own country 
as Americans are of ours. Some things I would take issue with you however 
are;
  No nation on Earth gets judged as much as the U.S.. Chinese and Russian 
governments simply don't care what their citizens and the world thinks of 
them, because the people running them will never face negative 
consequences. U.S. politicians are often arrested and / or voted out office 
for poor judgements, even when they affect nobody but the politicians 
themselves.
  Both China and Russia interfere with, bribe and out right take over other 
nations without the slightest repercussions from their own people or the 
rest of world.  Every single U.S. politician, from local officials to the 
President, are judged on a worldwide stage. Something that would be 
unthinkable in most other countries.
  Do we feel pride in our country? Yes. Is it irrational? Not in the 
slightest. We enjoy a standard of living that the vast majority of other 
countries in the world can't compete with. There is a reason people flock 
to the U.S., because opportunities exist here like no other nation in the 
world. Our taxes and regulations, however odious, are actually quite 
reasonable compared to that of most other countries. We give, not loan, 
more in foreign aid than other countries, even with respect to per capita 
spending. We, as citizens, win hands down as the largest charitable givers 
in the world.
  Do we have problems? Of coarse we do. We put in our nose in where we 
don't belong, far too often. We have serious issues with our prison system, 
race relations, education, money in politics and list goes on and on. But 
we can discuss and debate them openly and without fear.
  If you want a stark comparison try this; Go to Washington D.C. and yell 
insults, true or not about President Obama, right out the White house. Then 
go to either Beijing or Moscow and yell insults at their leaders right 
outside their offices (not even at their homes). Then when and if you get 
out of prison let me know how that worked out for you.
  In Chernobyl, right now, the sarcophagus covering the damaged nuclear 
facility is on the verge of collapse. The project to build a new cover has 
been delayed by another year and has run out of money ... again. The 
incredibly sad part of the story is that the entire project costs less than 
one billion dollars. The U.S. government spends more money than that on ink 
pens and toilet paper each year. The nations that would be the most 
affected, if the sarcophagus collapsed, can't raise the money to complete 
the repairs. And have now turned to the G-8 for money, with expectation 
that the U.S. is supposed to bail them out. Again.
  Yes the U.S. has problems, and anyone in the U.S. is free to leave 
anytime, any day if they don't like it here.
  Please don't mistake my honesty in facing our issues for being apologetic 
in slightest. Not one single nation in the world was built with clean hands 
and not one was created without bloodshed and oppression. The difference is 
this; in the U.S. we try to address our problems instead of ignoring them.
comments.author: Moreththerogue

comments.text:
+Moreththerogue Well the big difference is that China and Russia get judge 
over it, etc. while the US just gets away with it, whether that involves 
breaking international law or downright ignoring democracy and creating a 
dictatorship with no regards to human rights just to secure financial 
interest.
I understand that the population has little to no influence on what the 
government is doing in foreign politics, HOWEVER, what does annoy me is the 
sheer amount of Americans that somehow hold this irrational pride and 
feeling of superiority. That feel like America is better than others and 
that will try to justify any American actions.
comments.author: yakumo961

comments.text:
+yakumo961 If you really want to understand the U.S. government, and I 
specifically say government because most U.S. citizens would rather we kept 
our word, you only need to look up our history of treaties with the Native 
Americans. The U.S., Russia (and formerly the U.S.S.R.) and China all have 
very bad track records when it comes to remembering "inconvenient" 
treaties. It's a shame really because the world would be a better place if 
all governments kept their word. Unfortunately most only do so to bankers 
and whatever industries happen to make the most money at a given point in 
time.
comments.author: Moreththerogue
